citation.article-title: Transfer of Kingella indologenes (Snell and Lapage 1976) to the genus Suttonella gen. nov. as Suttonella indologenes comb. nov.; transfer of Bacteroides nodosus (Beveridge 1941) to the genus Dichelobacter gen. nov. as Dichelobacter nodosus comb. nov.; and assignment of the genera Cardiobacterium, Dichelobacter, and Suttonella to Cardiobacteriaceae fam. nov. in the gamma division of Proteobacteria on the basis of 16S rRNA sequence comparisons.

p.s: Description of the Suttonella gen. nov.
Suttonella (Sut.ton.el´la. L. dim. ending ella; N.L. fem. n. Suttonella, named after R. G. A. Sutton).
The description of the genus Suttonella below is based on the description of Snell and Lapage (36), supplemented with information from Bovre et al. (3) and Bruun et al. (5).
Straight rods that are 1.0 μm in diameter and 2 to 3 μm long and have rounded ends.
Cells occasionally occur in pairs, clusters, or chains.
Gram-negative, but there is a tendency to resist Gram decolorization.
Nonmotile as determined by normal tests, but may be fimbriated (pileated) and exhibit twitching motility.
Small translucent colonies grow on blood agar after 48 h of incubation at 37°C.
Pitting of media and spreading edges of colonies may be present with freshly isolated strains, but may be lost.
Aerobic.
Oxidase positive (when tested with tetramethyl-p-phenylene diamine).
Catalase negative.
Indole positive (activity may be weak).
Urease negative.
DNase negative.
Ornithine and lysine decarboxylase negative.
Chemoorganotrophic, having a strictly fermentative type of metabolism.
Acid but not gas is produced from glucose and a limited number of sugars.
Nitrates are not reduced.
H2S is produced (as determined by the lead acetate method, but not by the triple sugar iron method).
No growth occurs on MacConkey agar.
The G+C content of the DNA is 49 mol%.
The genus contains a single species, Suttonella indologenes.
